name: UnionRTLSDeviceAndRTLSDevice
title: Union of RTLS Tag Device Profile And RTLS Tag Device Profile

element.short: Item used in healthcare
element.definition: A type of a manufactured item that is used in the provision of healthcare without being substantially changed through that activity. The device may be a medical or non-medical device.

constraint.human: only one Device.name.display SHALL be true when there is more than one Device.name
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().ofType(canonical) | %resource.descendants().ofType(uri) | %resource.descendants().ofType(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(ofType(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(ofType(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: left: Within the context of the FHIR RESTful interactions, the resource has an id except for cases like the create and conditional update. Otherwise, the use of the resouce id depends on the given use case.; right: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: left: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of its narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.; right: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: left: IETF language tag for a human language; right: A human language.

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: left: Contained resources do not have a narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.; right: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: left: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This is allowed to be a Parameters resource if and only if it is referenced by a resource that provides context/meaning.; right: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags in their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: left: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.; right: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition:
left: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).; right: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions].

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Instance identifier
element.definition: Unique instance identifiers assigned to a device by manufacturers other organizations or owners.
element.comment: left: Certain attributes, like serial number and UDI Carrier (the HRF or AIDC barcode string) are not device instance identifiers as they are not consistently able to uniquely identify the instance of a device, thus are not appropriate to be used to value Device.identifier. The barcode string from a barcode present on a device label or package may identify the instance, include names given to the device in local usage, or may identify the type of device. If the identifier identifies the type of device, Device.type element should be used. The identifier is typically valued if the serialNumber or lotNumber is not valued and represents a different type of identifier.  However, it is permissible to still include those identifiers in DeviceDefinition.identifier with the appropriate identifier.type.; right: The barcode string from a barcode present on a device label or package may identify the instance, include names given to the device in local usage, or may identify the type of device. If the identifier identifies the type of device, Device.type element should be used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: The serial number which is a component of the production identifier (PI), a conditional, variable portion of a UDI.   The identifier.type code should be set to “SNO”(Serial Number) and the system left empty.

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The namespace for the identifier value
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: Identifier.system is always case sensitive.
element.requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The value that is unique
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-rendered-value.html). Identifier.value is to be treated as case sensitive unless knowledge of the Identifier.system allows the processer to be confident that non-case-sensitive processing is safe.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comment: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: The name used to display by default when the device is referenced
element.definition: The name used to display by default when the device is referenced. Based on intent of use by the resource creator, this may reflect one of the names in Device.name, or may be another simple name.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The reference to the definition for the device
element.definition: The reference to the definition for the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique Device Identifier (UDI) Barcode string
element.definition: Unique device identifier (UDI) assigned to device label or package.  Note that the Device may include multiple udiCarriers as it either may include just the udiCarrier for the jurisdiction it is sold, or for multiple jurisdictions it could have been sold.
element.comment: UDI may identify an unique instance of a device, or it may only identify the type of the device.  See [UDI mappings] for a complete mapping of UDI parts to Device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Mandatory fixed portion of UDI
element.definition: The device identifier (DI) is a mandatory, fixed portion of a UDI that identifies the labeler and the specific version or model of a device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: The device identifier (DI), a mandatory, fixed portion of a UDI that identifies the labeler and the specific version or model of a device.

element.short: UDI Issuing Organization
element.definition:
left: Organization that is charged with issuing UDIs for devices. For example, the US FDA issuers include: 
1) GS1: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/gs1-di, 
2) HIBCC: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/hibcc-diI, 
3) ICCBBA for blood containers: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-blood-di, 
4) ICCBA for other devices: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-other-di # Informationsstelle für Arzneispezialitäten (IFA GmbH) (EU only): http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/ifa-gmbh-di.; right: Organization that is charged with issuing UDIs for devices.  For example, the US FDA issuers include :
1) GS1: 
http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/gs1-di, 
2) HIBCC:
http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/hibcc-dI, 
3) ICCBBA for blood containers:
http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-blood-di, 
4) ICCBA for other devices:
http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-other-di.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map:
All UDIs are to be issued under a system operated by an Jurisdiction-accredited issuing agency.
GS1 DIs: 
 http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/gs1
HIBCC DIs:
 http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/hibcc
ICCBBA DIs for blood containers:
 http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-blood
ICCBA DIs for other devices:
 http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-other

element.short: Regional UDI authority
element.definition: left: The identity of the authoritative source for UDI generation within a jurisdiction. All UDIs are globally unique within a single namespace with the appropriate repository uri as the system. For example, UDIs of devices managed in the U.S. by the FDA, the value is http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/us-fda-udi or in the European Union by the European Commission http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/eu-ec-udi.; right: The identity of the authoritative source for UDI generation within a  jurisdiction.  All UDIs are globally unique within a single namespace with the appropriate repository uri as the system.  For example,  UDIs of devices managed in the U.S. by the FDA, the value is  http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/fda-udi.
element.requirements: Allows a recipient of a UDI to know which database will contain the UDI-associated metadata.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: UDI Machine Readable Barcode String
element.definition: The full UDI carrier of the Automatic Identification and Data Capture (AIDC) technology representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device - e.g., a barcode or RFID.   Because of limitations on character sets in XML and the need to round-trip JSON data through XML, AIDC Formats *SHALL* be base64 encoded.
element.comment: The AIDC form of UDIs should be scanned or otherwise used for the identification of the device whenever possible to minimize errors in records resulting from manual transcriptions. If separate barcodes for DI and PI are present, concatenate the string with DI first and in order of human readable expression on label.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: A unique device identifier (UDI) on a device label a form that uses automatic identification and data capture (AIDC) technology.

element.short: UDI Human Readable Barcode String
element.definition: The full UDI carrier as the human readable form (HRF) representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device.
element.comment: If separate barcodes for DI and PI are present, concatenate the string with DI first and in order of human readable expression on label.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: A unique device identifier (UDI) on a device label in plain text

element.short: left: barcode | rfid | manual | card | self-reported | electronic-transmission | unknown; right: barcode | rfid | manual +
element.definition: A coded entry to indicate how the data was entered.
element.requirements: Supports a way to distinguish hand entered from machine read data.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes to identify how UDI data was entered.

element.short: A status of "active" indicates that a tracking tag is in use (regardless of current assignment to a subject) and "inactive" indicates that a tracking tag is no longer in use.
element.definition: left: The Device record status. This is not the status of the device like availability.; right: Status of the Device availability.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes inactive and entered-in-error that mark the device (record)as not currently valid.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: left: The record status of the device.; right: The availability status of the device.

element.short: lost | damaged | destroyed | available
element.definition: The availability of the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The availability status reason of the device.

element.short: An identifier that supports traceability to the event during which material in this product from one or more biological entities was obtained or pooled
element.definition: An identifier that supports traceability to the event during which material in this product from one or more biological entities was obtained or pooled.
element.comment: Necessary to support mandatory requirements for traceability from donor/source to recipient and vice versa, while also satisfying donor anonymity requirements. The element is defined consistently across BiologicallyDerivedProduct, NutritionProduct, and Device.  The identifier references an event that links to a single biological entity such as a blood donor, or to multiple biological entities (e.g. when the product is an embryo or a pooled platelet product).  A single biologicalSourceEvent identifier may appear on multiple products of many types derived from a single donation event or source extraction.  As an example, a single donation event may provide 2 kidneys and a liver for organ transplantation, 2 corneas for eye surgery, heart valves and arterial tissue for cardiovascular surgery, multiple skin grafts, tendons, multiple shaped bone grafts and a large number of bone putty/paste products; and each of them may be assigned to the same biological source event identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name of device manufacturer
element.definition: left: A name of the manufacturer or entity legally responsible for the device.; right: A name of the manufacturer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Date when the device was made
element.definition: The date and time when the device was manufactured.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: The date a specific device was manufactured - which is a component of the production identifier (PI), a conditional, variable portion of a UDI.  For FHIR, The datetime syntax must converted to YYYY-MM-DD[THH:MM:SS].  If hour is present, the minutes and seconds should both be set to “00”.

element.short: Date and time of expiry of this device (if applicable)
element.definition: The date and time beyond which this device is no longer valid or should not be used (if applicable).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: the expiration date of a specific device -  which is a component of the production identifier (PI), a conditional, variable portion of a UDI.  For FHIR, The datetime syntax must converted to YYYY-MM-DD[THH:MM:SS].  If hour is present, the minutes and seconds should both be set to “00”.

element.short: Lot number of manufacture
element.definition: Lot number assigned by the manufacturer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: The lot or batch number within which a device was manufactured - which is a component of the production identifier (PI), a conditional, variable portion of a UDI.

element.short: Serial number assigned by the manufacturer
element.definition: The serial number assigned by the organization when the device was manufactured.
element.comment: left: Alphanumeric Maximum 20. While a serial number is a type of identifier, in the context of devices for which a UDI is required, thus a serial number may be part of the production identifier, it is more informative to have the serial number as a dedicated attribute together with the other UDI production identifier.  When the device is not subject to including the UDI (e.g., its presence and exchange is not mandated by local regulatory requirements or specific use case at hand), thus the concept of production identifiers is not relevant as a set, it remains helpful for consistency to still use Device.serialNumber rather than using Device.identifier with an appropriate type.  Systems that do not realize an identifier is a serial number may place it in Device.identifier or if the identifier.system is known for the serial number, it may also be populated in the Device.identifier as a globally unique id_.; right: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The name or names of the device as known to the manufacturer and/or patient
element.definition: This represents the manufacturer's name of the device as provided by the device, from a UDI label, or by a person describing the Device.  This typically would be used when a person provides the name(s) or when the device represents one of the names available from DeviceDefinition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: left: The manufacturer's model number for the device; right: The model number for the device
element.definition: left: The manufacturer's model number for the device.; right: The model number for the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: left: The part number or catalog number of the device; right: The part number of the device
element.definition: left: The part number or catalog number of the device.; right: The part number of the device.
element.comment: Alphanumeric Maximum 20.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Indicates a high-level grouping of the device
element.definition: Devices may be associated with one or more categories.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The kind or type of device
element.definition: left: The kind or type of device. A device instance may have more than one type - in which case those are the types that apply to the specific instance of the device.; right: The kind or type of device.
element.comment: Multiple device types are use when a device is categorized in more than one context – for example, hybrid devices in which the device is both of type gateway and sensor.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device
element.definition: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: left: The type of the device version, e.g. manufacturer, approved, internal; right: The type of the device version
element.definition: left: The type of the device version, e.g. manufacturer, approved, internal.; right: The type of the device version.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of version indicated for the device.

element.short: left: The hardware or software module of the device to which the version applies; right: A single component of the device version
element.definition: left: The hardware or software module of the device to which the version applies.; right: A single component of the device version.
element.comment: Note that the module of the device would not need to be tracked as a separate device, e.g., using different UDI, thus would typically involve one or more software modules. For example, a device may involve two software modules each on a different version.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The date the version was installed on the device
element.definition: The date the version was installed on the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The version text
element.definition: The version text.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Identifies the standards, specifications, or formal guidances for the capabilities supported by the device
element.definition: Identifies the standards, specifications, or formal guidances for the capabilities supported by the device. The device may be certified as conformant to these specifications e.g., communication, performance, process, measurement, or specialization standards.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: left: Inherent, essentially fixed, characteristics of the device.  e.g., time properties, size, material, etc.; right: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties
element.definition: left: Static or essentially fixed characteristics or features of the device (e.g., time or timing attributes, resolution, accuracy, intended use or instructions for use, and physical attributes) that are not otherwise captured in more specific attributes.; right: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties.
element.comment: Dynamic or current properties, such as settings, of an individual device are described using a Device instance-specific [DeviceMetric] and recorded using [Observation].  Static characteristics of a device could also be documented in an associated [DeviceDefinition] instance. The Device instance's properties, and their values, could be, but need not be, the same as those described in an associated DeviceDefinition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: left: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: left: Code that specifies the property being represented; right: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible)
element.definition: left: Code that specifies the property, such as resolution, color, size, being represented.; right: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Value of the property
element.definition: The value of the property specified by the associated property.type code.
element.comment: The text element in CodeableConcept.text is used for properties which would usually be coded (such as the size of an implant, or a security classification) but for which there is not currently an appropriate concept in the vocabulary (e.g. a custom implant size, or a security classification which depends on configuration). Otherwise the string choice type is used for descriptive properties, or instructions.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Property value as a quantity
element.definition: Property value as a quantity.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP)
element.definition: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The designated condition for performing a task
element.definition: The designated condition for performing a task with the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The series of occurrences that repeats during the operation of the device
element.definition: The series of occurrences that repeats during the operation of the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A measurement of time during the device's operation (e.g., days, hours, mins, etc.)
element.definition: A measurement of time during the device's operation (e.g., days, hours, mins, etc.).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Organization responsible for device
element.definition: An organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Details for human/organization for support
element.definition: Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device.
element.comment: used for troubleshooting etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Where the device is found
element.definition: The place where the device can be found.
element.requirements: Device.location can be used to track device location.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Network address to contact device
element.definition: A network address on which the device may be contacted directly.
element.comment: If the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should  be the Base URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Technical endpoints providing access to electronic services provided by the device
element.definition: Technical endpoints providing access to services provided by the device defined at this resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Linked device acting as a communication/data collector, translator or controller
element.definition: The linked device acting as a communication controller, data collector, translator, or concentrator for the current device (e.g., mobile phone application that relays a blood pressure device's data).
element.comment: The Device.gateway may be used when the Device being referenced has a gateway and/or to capture one or more gateways associated with the device. If the Gateway is included in the Observation resource, the Observation.gatewayDevice should be used instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Device notes and comments
element.definition: Descriptive information, usage information or implantation information that is not captured in an existing element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Safety Characteristics of Device
element.definition: Provides additional safety characteristics about a medical device.  For example devices containing latex.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: left: The higher level or encompassing device that this device is a logical part of; right: The parent device
element.definition: left: The higher level or encompassing device that this device is a logical part of.; right: The parent device.
element.comment: For example a vital signs monitor (parent) where three separate modules can be plugged into such as interchangeable blood pressure, oximeter, temperature modules.  These modules are represented as devices with the .parent valued to the vital signs monitor when plugged in.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: online | paused | standby | offline | not-ready | transduc-discon | hw-discon | off
element.definition: Reason for the dtatus of the Device availability.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The availability status reason of the device.

element.short: The distinct identification string
element.definition: The distinct identification string as required by regulation for a human cell, tissue, or cellular and tissue-based product.
element.comment: For example, this applies to devices in the United States regulated under *Code of Federal Regulation 21CFR§1271.290(c)*.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: The lot or batch number within which a device was manufactured - which is a component of the production identifier (PI), a conditional, variable portion of a UDI.

element.short: The name of the device as given by the manufacturer
element.definition: This represents the manufacturer's name of the device as provided by the device, from a UDI label, or by a person describing the Device.  This typically would be used when a person provides the name(s) or when the device represents one of the names available from DeviceDefinition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The capabilities supported on a  device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication
element.definition: The capabilities supported on a  device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Patient to whom Device is affixed
element.definition: Patient information, If the device is affixed to a person.
element.requirements: If the device is implanted in a patient, then need to associate the device to the patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
